p:
From the LIG to the LGM, concomitant with climate cooling, most Rhodiola species expanded their geographic ranges, consistent with what happened with R. integrifolia in North America
32, 33 . A similar pattern was also detected in other QTP plants including Taxus wallichiana and Picea likiangensis
34, 35 . Thus, as would be expected of cold-adapted species responding to climate warming
5, 6, 36 , we found that Rhodiola species have generally shifted upward in altitude and also northward since the LGM (Fig. 3; Supplementary Tables S10 and S12; Supplementary Figs S2– S4). Although our estimates of upward rate of movement varied somewhat using different modelling approaches, the mean elevation upward movement of Rhodiola (0.273~7.07 m/year) is similar to estimates of upward movement rate for the tree line in the Baima Mountains of the HM (0.84 m/year, between 1923 to 2003)
37 and montane herbaceous plants in Europe (8 m/year estimated from Fig. 4 in Lenoir et al.
6 ). We have no estimates for rate of latitudinal movement in plants, although the northward rate of range shifting of Rhodiola (0.288~1.24 km/year) is comparable to that of animals (1.69 km/year)
5 .
